title: How to Determine the Wood Type Used in Furniture

steps.title: Examine the wood for scratches and dents to determine if it is softwood.
steps.content: Examine the wood for scratches and dents to determine if it is softwood. Harder woods are more resistant to scratches and dents, so if you don’t see any, the furniture may be made out of hardwood. A piece of furniture that has many scratches and dents may be made out of softwood. [1] X Research source Try scratching an inconspicuous area of the furniture with your fingernail if you don’t notice any marks to see if it is easy to put a mark into, which can indicate that it is made out of softwood. Softwoods come from conifers like pine, redwood, and cedar.

steps.title: Identify pine by its yellow color, straight grain, and abundance of knots.
steps.content: Identify pine by its yellow color, straight grain, and abundance of knots. Feel for a smooth grain texture if the wood looks yellowish and has a straight grain. Look for darker growth rings in addition to an abundance of knots. [2] X Research source Remember that if your furniture is stained or weathered, it will be harder to tell what kind of wood it is based on the color. You can still try to determine what it is from other features like the grain pattern. Pine is used frequently for indoor rustic casual furniture like tables and dressers, for example.

steps.title: Spot cedar by its rich red color, straight grain, and unique scent.
steps.content: Spot cedar by its rich red color, straight grain, and unique scent. Feel the grain to check if it is smooth if the wood looks reddish and has a straight grain. Smell the wood closely for an aromatic woodsy scent for a key giveaway. [3] X Research source Cedar is commonly used in outdoor furniture because of its weather resistance, as well as to build indoor furniture like wardrobes and chests because of its moth repellent properties.

steps.title: Recognize redwood by its dark red color and wavy grain.
steps.content: Recognize redwood by its dark red color and wavy grain. Look for redwood’s signature marled reddish-brown and mahogany colors and curvy, intricate grain patterns. It is similar in appearance to cedar but has a darker, more elegant red color. [4] X Research source Redwood is commonly used for outdoor furniture because it is very weather-resistant. If you can’t decide whether a piece of wood furniture that is red is made out of cedar or redwood, smell it. Redwood does not have the woodsy aromatic scent that cedar does.

steps.title: Identify Douglas fir by its light brown color and its tight straight grain.
steps.content: Identify Douglas fir by its light brown color and its tight straight grain. Douglas fir can have hints of red or yellow between its growth rings. The grain pattern is usually very subtle and typically has knots in the growth rings. [5] X Research source Douglas fir is usually used for cheaper applications, so if your furniture is not expensive and it is made out of softwood, it might be made from Douglas fir. Painted furniture is often made out of douglas fir as well, because of the fact that the grain pattern is not super prominent.

steps.title: Inspect the wood grain for textures that indicate it is a hardwood.
steps.content: Inspect the wood grain for textures that indicate it is a hardwood. Softwoods usually have smooth grain patterns, while hardwoods have rougher, more porous patterns. Look at the grain and feel it with your fingertips to determine if it has the texture of a hardwood. [6] X Research source Hardwoods come from flowering trees like walnuts, oak, and maple. Some hardwoods, such as maple, have smooth grain patterns like softwoods do.

steps.title: Spot oak by its light brown color, straight grain, and visible growth rings.
steps.content: Spot oak by its light brown color, straight grain, and visible growth rings. Look at and feel the grain to see if it is porous. Verify that the wood has darker growth rings and very few knots. [7] X Research source Both red oak and white oak are commonly used in furniture and have a similar light brown color. However, as the name implies, red oak can have some hints of red in it. Oak can be used to make all kinds of furniture, including built-in furniture like cabinets. It is also commonly used for homewares like cutting boards.

steps.title: Recognize maple by its light creamy or yellow color and unusual grain patterns.
steps.content: Recognize maple by its light creamy or yellow color and unusual grain patterns. Look for unique patterns in the grain and a lack of straight grain to spot maple wood. It is a light creamy color when it is fresh and darkens to more of a yellowish color over time. [8] X Research source Maple is mostly used for indoor applications where the woodgrain is highly visible because of its unique and beautiful grain patterns. For example, high-end dining room tables and chairs are often made out of maple.

steps.title: Identify walnut by its dark tan or chocolate brown color and straight grain.
steps.content: Identify walnut by its dark tan or chocolate brown color and straight grain. The most common type of walnut used in furniture is black walnut, which sometimes has streaks of purple or green mixed in with its rich brown color. Look for slightly darker growth rings mixed into the straight grain to spot walnut furniture. [9] X Research source If the wood is from a young walnut tree that was still growing, it can also have pale yellow growth rings that contrast the dark growth rings. Walnut is expensive, so it is typically only used for high-end luxury furniture. It is often used in ornate carved furniture, such as mantelpieces or headboards.

steps.title: Recognize mahogany by its pinkish or reddish-brown color and smooth texture.
steps.content: Recognize mahogany by its pinkish or reddish-brown color and smooth texture. Mahogany has a fine long grain with few knots, so look for these qualities in addition to the color and texture. It starts out almost pink in color and darkens over time, so consider the age of the furniture when you are deciding if the color indicates that it is made out of mahogany. [10] X Research source Mahogany is used to make many types of furniture and is often used as a cheaper alternative to walnut.

steps.title: Look for a very light color and wide spacing between growth rings to spot ash.
steps.content: Look for a very light color and wide spacing between growth rings to spot ash. Ash tends to be beige or very light brown. The growth rings are typically light brown as well and often almost blend into the surrounding grain. [11] X Research source Ash can look similar to oak, but generally has less brown hues in its color and never has red hues.

steps.title: Identify beech by its cream tone and straight and tight grain pattern.
steps.content: Identify beech by its cream tone and straight and tight grain pattern. Look for yellow or reddish hints in the cream color. The grain pattern often has gray flecks in it as well. [12] X Research source Beech wood is often used to make curved pieces of furniture, such as curvy chairs, because it bends well using steam.

steps.title: Look at the end grains of the wood to see if there is exposed engineered wood.
steps.content: Look at the end grains of the wood to see if there is exposed engineered wood. Inspect the wood grain pattern on top of the wood and follow it with your eyes to the end of the piece. Check if the grain goes all the way through the piece of wood or if it is missing a grain pattern and looks like fake engineered wood. [13] X Research source If the end grain looks different and doesn’t have the same wood grain pattern wrapping around, the furniture is probably made out of engineered MDF, OSB, or particleboard, rather than a solid piece of wood, and laminated with veneers made to imitate the look of wood. If your furniture is made out of laminated MDF, OSB, or particleboard, the end grains will usually look like sawdust or wood shavings compacted and glued together. They could have a strip of veneer glued to them to hide the engineered wood’s appearance, but the grain pattern won’t match that on the surface of the furniture.

steps.title: Check for repeating wood grain patterns to spot veneers.
steps.content: Check for repeating wood grain patterns to spot veneers. Look at the wood grain patterns on the top, sides, and front of your piece of furniture. Repeating patterns mean that it is veneered and not made out of a solid piece of wood, which would have unique wood grain patterns all over. [14] X Research source Veneers are typically made from either printed laminate or wood-colored plastic made to resemble wood grain.

steps.title: Examine the sides and bottoms of drawers to discover fake wood.
steps.content: Examine the sides and bottoms of drawers to discover fake wood. Open up drawers if the furniture has any and look at the side pieces, the bottoms, and the backs of the front pieces. Look at the wood grain and end grain patterns to determine if the drawers are made out of solid wood or veneered engineered wood. [15] X Research source If you don’t spot any signs of man-made wood composites or plastic veneers meant to imitate the appearance of wood, you can proceed to try and identify the type of solid wood used to build the furniture. If you do notice that your furniture is made out of engineered products, there is nothing to identify.
